thread.title: This Woman in China Might Have the Least Sad Desk Lunch in the World
thread.title_full: This Woman in China Might Have the Least Sad Desk Lunch in the World

author: Mayukh Sen
title: This Woman in China Might Have the Least Sad Desk Lunch in the World
text:
This Woman in China Might Have the Least Sad Desk Lunch in the World Your Late-Night, Bad-Day Alternative to Ordering Nachos at the Bar A Pantry-Clearing, Belly-Warming Lentil and Chickpea Soup How to Make Any Type of Irish Soda Bread from Classic to Crazy Four &Twenty Blackbirds Matcha Custard Pie Barbara Kafka’s Creamy Lemon Pasta Ruth's Brisket ␡ Follow friends and influencers By following your friends and influencers you'll be able to see what they're saving in real time. Cooking is more fun with friends. Find your friends who are already on Food52, and invite others who aren't to join.   
Must an office desk lunch be sad? No; of course not. We’ve spent years debunking this fiction, traveling across the country showing companies far and near just how happy a desk lunch can be if done with love. 
Someone's encroaching on our turf, though. She goes by “Little Ye,” and, as of January , she’s a sensation on YouTube, with her videos circulating across Chinese social network Weibo. She's amassed a truckload of followers: 45,000 and counting. Advertisement 
Her videos hew to a similar narrative pattern: They usually begin with shots of office drones droning away at computers, silent and heads-down, before Little Ye gets to work. She scrounges around the office for any supplies she can find and turn into makeshift cooking tools, from clothes irons to Pepsi cans; computer casings become pancake friers. She preps noodles atop bunsen burners, prepping literal feasts, and her coworkers go on with their days as if nothing’s going on. 
Impressive, no? Really thought we had this Not Sad Desk Lunch thing down. Ugh. We’ve got to start upping our game!
